statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Montana State 72, Montana 62
article.story: BOZEMAN, Mont. (AP) -- It was appropriate that Casey Durham would have such a game. No one else on the floor except his father has as much Cat-Griz history. Durham, a freshman guard and son of Montana State coach Mick Durham, connected on 6-of-10 shots from long range in the Bobcat's 72-62 victory Sunday over Montana, completing a regular-season sweep of the Grizzlies. Durham came off the bench to lead all scorers with 18 points in the 271st matchup between the schools. "That's what he does -- make three's and be a pest on defense. No other player has seen as many Cat-Griz games as Casey. It means a lot to him," said coach Durham. "For my family and my friends, this is what we live for -- to sweep the Grizzlies," Casey Durham said. Montana State (13-10, 8-2 Big Sky) led 49-32 following a 3-pointer off the glass by Durham at the 13:31 mark, but saw its lead shrink to 51-44 after Kevin Criswell's layup with 7:37 remaining to cap a seven-point Grizzly run. Ja'Ron Jefferson hit 1-of-2 free throws to put MSU back up 52-44 after Montana's Matt Dlouhy was called for a technical foul after stepping on the end line. Jefferson was fouled on the ensuing possession and sank both free throws to give the Bobcats a 54-44 lead and Branden Miller's 3-pointer with 5:12 left put MSU up 57-44. Montana (12-11, 6-4) fell behind 70-53 on Marvin Moss' layup with 1:30 remaining before outscoring the Bobcats 9-2 the rest of the way. UM coach Larry Krystkowiak called the loss "a good old-fashioned whippin'. I'm not saying they're a better team than us, but they were tonight, so good for them." Marvin Moss scored 13 points for the Bobcats and Miller had 12 on 4-of-11 shooting from 3-point range, where the Bobcats connected on 12-of-31 shots. "We tried to pick up the tempo on defense and that's what you give up, some open three's," Krystkowiak said. Kamarr Davis led UM with 16 points and Dlouhy had 12. UM opened the second half with a seven-point run and cut the Bobcats' lead to 33-27 on Dlouhy's second consecutive put-back with 18:08 left. Moss answered with a layup at the 17:48 mark, but Dlouhy hit a 3-pointer to pull UM to 35-30 with 17:35 left. Two free throws by Pratt and the second of two straight 3-pointers by Miller gave MSU a 43-30 advantage with 15:08 remaining. The first 10 minutes of the game saw three lead changes and three ties. After Davis' short hook at the 10:40 mark pulled UM to 14-13, MSU scored seven straight to take 21-13 lead on Durham's 3-pointer with 8:24 left in the half. Andrew Stait's layup with 4:17 remaining cut MSU's lead to 23-17, but the Bobcats reeled off seven staight once again and went up 30-17 on Taylor Pratt's bucket off an alley oop pass from Branden Miller with 1:28 left. Montana State held a 33-20 advantage at the break.
